"What are all integer sequences such that ?"

This is somewhat in the flavour of 2009 N4 if I were to ask for finite sequences, and there are a lot of case bashing which I didn't like. So I asked for an infinite sequence having this property.

This turned out to be impossible, and very easily seen to be the case: eventually increasing but not constant, yet it means they increase by at least , making the polynomial too small.

Then I tried to vary the polynomial a bit, say , thinking maybe its "huge enough". It turns out that also had no solutions, with some more effort, and is the first polynomial that works.

This is quite exciting to me, because finally I see a positive result. I thought this is the only polynomial, but very quickly I realized any AP with difference and works.

Immediately I generalize the problem to this:

"For which quadratic polynomials can there exist an infinite sequence of positive integers such that ?"

This turns out to be much much harder, because already the sequence has to be an AP, and the difference is fixed to be , and yet we only know the sequence is increasing. This indicates a huge increase in difficulty than at first glance. I worked on this for a few hours and finally solved it, using most of the main ideas (which I will leave that to you guys :p) in the final version. I already felt this problem is special because it uses ideas like Pigeonhole principle and bounding the second leading coefficient, and finally resolving the solution with remainder theorem on polynomials.

I very much liked the fact that it combines polynomials with sequences in the problem statement, whose solution involves algebra, combinatorics and NT. It also resolves a huge class of integer sequence problems of sufficient beauty [Of course, sequence problems often can be designed as artificial as possible, but I think this form is one of the most natural and nicest to consider]

Motivation
As with a lot of problems, the "hidden" case gives you the answer but the base case really gives you some intuition. When you write down , you quickly see that or vice versa, and that it would generalize easily. So you really want to show that you can write in such a form.

Then, the divine inspiration of "if we have terms on both sides, what if they're all equal" comes up when looking at
This is pretty inspiring, but a dead end.

On the other end, the sequence seems really interesting. There are quite a few number theoretic properties, but they're hard to really use. Looking at the other interpretations of positive integers, one of the keys is the ability to well-order them. This is interesting because the second we look at a minimum, it must be at the beginning. Wow.

So we know that the sequence is increasing, which is interesting. The next natural question is "how increasing", which after work is constant increasing. So we have some strict bounds and want to show something happens infinitely often - Pigeonhole. The rest follows.

Remarks
I think the idea of disguising this as Number Theory is brilliant because "positive integers" is such a weird red herring. It gives the natural impression of being number theory, but the idea that only arithmetic sequences seem to work make the combination really weird. So instead you have to try an algebraic approach.

This also seems very natural when you look at degrees and instead of trying to distribute prime factors, you just assume things are equal. This intuition is really helpful in reducing the problem to showing has linear (integer) factors. Once again, trying something like quadratic discriminants or whatever is appeasing but they don't address the integer part of it, so you have to look to something different.

This is where my love for the problem comes. Pigeonhole? In my algebra? Wow. I particularly like how the idea of combining Pigeonhole with the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra is fairly common but the way they work in tandem here is overshadowed by a much more massive problem; how to get to a point where you can apply it. But once you know more about the sequence I feel that this comes naturally.

I think this is an extremely appropriately selected and constructed IMO #3. This solution, even though it's somewhat short, is not particularly easy to find. It took me quite a while to get to the proof of the main claim, and even more to understand why it helped finish.

As said earlier, the big red herring of positive integers implying number theory is a real catch here. Many contestants I know personally tried chasing the number theoretic approach and got nowhere.

Even if you've convinced yourself that it's an algebra problem, the question is where to go next. Looking at the sequence, it is not immediately obvious why it should be increasing, or whether that should be the case. You know that in each block of , it should increase a bit, but nothing that's enough to suggest the immediate claim.

I feel that all of these challenges and the way these ideas work together make this problem brilliant. Thank you Ivan for this gem.
